course_title: The Policy and Practice of Crime Control and Crime Prevention

learning_outcomes.description: Capacity to recognise, assess and generate evidence-based crime policies.
Ability to scrutinize the integrity and effectiveness of different crime policies.
Understanding of the complexities in adopting evidence-based crime policies.
Ability to identify rigorous evaluation methods to inform evidence-based crime policies
Work collaboratively with others and complete group work tasks

assessments.task_description:
The major item of assessment for this course is a research project that will allow students to develop their ability to analyse community problems and identify possible solutions. Students are asked to develop a management and/or prevention strategy for a real community problem. This can be a problem that you have experienced or witnessed in your local neighbourhood, place of work or study. In conducting your project you should follow the problem-orientated methodology:  S – Scan; A – Analyse; R- Respond; A - Assess.

This first hurdle assessment is an opportunity for the student to demonstrate that they have identified an appropriate problem and method for the focus of their report. The submission of the form is required to pass the course. You will not be marked on the content, however it will give me (the lecturer) an opportunity to help students make modifications to their plans if required. The online form has two questions:

  1. What is community problem that you will focus on for your project and where is the problem?
  2. How do you think you will be able to document evidence about the problem? (for example, observations and photos; interviews; police statistics; newspaper/document analysis).
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must complete the online form through blackboard electronically by the due time on the due date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment 1 comprises of two parts. Assessment 1a requires that you prepare and present your research problem and proposed project (the one outlined in the preliminary assessment) to a group of peers. Styled like the TV show "The Apprentice" you will have a 2 minutes to pitch your problem and convince the group of why research is urgently needed. The pitch sessions will take place in weeks 6 (1/4) and 7 (15/4) so please plan accordingly to make sure you can attend. There will be no supplementary assessments. You must attend and present on one of the two days to pass. You will submit a video of your in-class pitch. You can get a peer to film you on your own phone. Please note that all assessment must be completed to pass this course.

In addition to the in-class pitch you will be required to complete a written worksheet about your research problem and project. This will need to be submitted along with your video via turn it in. See blackboard for more details.

This piece of assessment is worth 10% of your grade (5% for submission of your video; 5% for submission of a completed, quality worksheet). You must participate in both the presentation in class and submit the worksheet to pass this course. You will give your pitch to a group of your peers in class in weeks 6 (1/4) and 7 (15/4) - there are no extensions on this component. The worksheet and the video are due on the 15th of April by 2pm. Please upload to the turn it in links.

Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessments’ folder on Blackboard Ultra for this course.

assessments.task_description:
In weeks 6 (1/4) and 7(15/4) you and your peers will have the opportunity to 'pitch' your community problems and research projects to groups in the class. In addition to pitching your own problem, you will also need to select one peers' presentation to reflect on. You must submit a 2-3 page reflection of a peer's research problem pitch. Your reflection should address the following questions:

What is the problem they are presenting?

What might be some of the potential causes and appropriate prevention approaches in the context they are describing?

This assessment is due via Turnitin on the 22nd of April. Please see blackboard Ultra for the detailed tasksheet and criteria.

assessments.task_description:
The major item of assessment for this course is a research project that will allow students to develop their ability to analyse community problems and identify possible solutions. Students are asked to develop a management and/or prevention strategy for a real community problem. You can use a problem in your local neighbourhood, place of work or another place where you spend time. You will have the opportunity to collect your own empirical evidence about the problem (scan), analyse what we know about the problem and how others have responded to the problem in other contexts, offer recommendations to respond to the problem in the context of your own research site, and suggest how the suggested response might be assessed or evaluated.

We will learn about each of the components of the Scan, Analyse, Respond, Assess model in class and we will also practice ways to collect empirical evidence through observation (e.g. photos); interviews and surveys; newspaper/social media content analysis. Detailed information is available on blackboard Ultra, including the marking criteria. Due on the 27th of May.

Week 12: Policy, people and places

In this seminar we will discuss ways in which policy and program effects can vary across population groups and identify global variations in criminal justice approaches.

  • Juvenile justice
  • Drug Policies
  • Do fines unfairly impact those who are already poor?
  • Critiquing policy and programs - who do they really work for?

Applied learning: how can you make a difference? - writing parliamentary submissions.
